question: Outline what happens to the C–H and C–O bonds when a primary alcohol is oxidised to a carboxylic acid.

sample_answer.full_answer: Oxidation decreases C–H bonds and increases C–O bonds, converting -CH2OH to -COOH (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: States loss of C–H and gain of C–O bonds in oxidation.

question: Explain why PCC converts a primary alcohol to an aldehyde whereas KMnO4 converts it to a carboxylic acid.

sample_answer.full_answer: PCC is a mild oxidant in anhydrous conditions, stopping at the aldehyde stage (1 mark). KMnO4 is a strong oxidant in aqueous solution and continues oxidation to the acid (1 mark). Water provides oxygen for further oxidation (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: Describes PCC as mild/anhydrous stopping at aldehyde.
Describes KMnO4 as strong oxidant giving acid.
Mentions presence of water enabling further oxidation.

common_mistakes: Claiming PCC cannot oxidise primary alcohols.

question: Predict the product when cyclohexene undergoes oxidative cleavage with hot KMnO4, and calculate the number of carbon atoms lost as CO2.

sample_answer.full_answer: Cyclohexene cleaves to produce adipic acid (HOOC-(CH2)4-COOH) (2 marks). No carbon atoms lost as CO2 because each double-bond carbon becomes part of the dicarboxylic acid (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Notes zero carbon atoms lost as CO2.

common_mistakes: Assuming CO2 is released from internal alkenes.

question: Compare NaBH4 and catalytic hydrogenation (H2/Ni) for reducing carbonyl compounds, focusing on scope and conditions.

sample_answer.full_answer: NaBH4 selectively reduces aldehydes and ketones in protic solvents at room temperature (2 marks). H2/Ni reduces carbonyls and unsaturated bonds but requires elevated temperature/pressure (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Describes NaBH4 scope and mild conditions.
Describes catalytic hydrogenation scope and harsher conditions.

question: Devise a synthesis to convert benzaldehyde to 1-phenylethanol using redox chemistry. Include reagents, stereochemical considerations, and theoretical yield when starting with 0.200 mol benzaldehyde.

sample_answer.full_answer: Step 1: Perform Grignard addition with CH3MgBr to form secondary alkoxide (1 mark). Step 2: Protonate to yield racemic 1-phenylethanol (1 mark). Reaction adds CH3 and reduces carbonyl (2 marks). Theoretical yield = 0.200 mol (molar mass 122.17 g mol^-1) → 24.4 g (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: States formation of Grignard reagent and addition step.
Explains redox aspect and stereochemical outcome (racemic).

common_mistakes: Attempting simple hydrogenation which does not add carbon.
